ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to use Gaussian and some of the theory behinds the methods used in computational chemistry.
Born-Oppenheimer approximation, Hartree-Fock, DFT, Solvation, QM/MM
You learn about all the work Gaussian does for you during your calculations in addition to the certain parameters you should select.
A deeper understanding of quantum chemistry and the ability to determine which computational method works best for a particular system.

Taking this class really helped me understand the basis behind computational chemistry; I now have an understanding for what programs like Gaussian do when you submit a calculation, and how far the field as a whole has come. I am not a theorist but I feel that I have learned a lot of rudimentary tools that I can use should I ever need to, and that I am now better able to comprehend literature that is partly or completely about theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professor is a huge strength of the course, and she is certainly focused on our learning more than anything else. As someone who is more interested in theory, I wish the lectures/homework pertained a bit more to the theory side rather than pure application, but I do not know if this would even be possible for a half semester class given the limited prerequisites.
Very fast paced but comprehensive introduction to computation chemistry. Very nice lecturer and TA.
I really enjoyed the labs and final project since that is where I learned the most.

I think this class should make the graduate-level quantum chemistry course a prerequisite, rather than an optional choice. Although this class focuses on application rather than mathematics, having a solid understanding of the theory beforehand would certainly be more helpful.

I really liked that this class was focused on us having fun and learning something. Having our grades based only on the labs and the final took a lot of pressure off during the semester, and I feel that I was better able to learn such a complex subject better this way.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend the course. However like most other upper level courses, it becomes what you put into it.
Definitely, a very good intro and excellent hands-on training for Gauss.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. There is still a lot I don't know about computational chemistry, but this class was really engaging and I feel that I now have a much better understanding of the field and how to run computations than I did at the start.
